markdownRemark.html:
For a new side project, Keming, my partner and I needed to quickly validate interest in our product. To do so, we designed and built landing page scoped to the following constraints:

  1. Allow users to submit interest and personal data
  2. Store this data safely, in an easily accessible and manipulable format
  3. Retain control over all styling (no 3rd-party branding should be evident)
  4. No server-side code
  5. Completely static and easily deployable through Netlify

As we are bootstrapping Keming, we did not have an immediate requirement for a fully-fledged backend - even a basic Flask application felt like overkill. At the same time, we did not want to release with a Google Form as we hypothesized the market we are targeting would be put off by something so crude.

My initial thought was to create a form that submits to the Google Sheets API. Having consumed Google’s API’s for years, I believed this would be a straight forward experience as the quality of their API design and documentation is typically superb. The documentation for Firebase is a salient example. However, I found the Google Sheets API documentation to be lacking and its implementation to complicated for such a simple project.

I briefly considered using Firebase as it is my standard for prototyping, but decided against it as it does not provide an interface for easily accessing and manipulating data.

Furthermore, I wanted to scratch that itch to use a new API…

Airtable
